The figures show that the number of cases in which failure in Irish was the cause of their not obtaining the certificate was only .2 per cent of the total and that those who failed in Irish failed in practically every other subject. At least, if a pass in Irish were not insisted upon, people would no longer have that excuse and would not be in a position to claim that the future of the child had been jeopardised because of failure in Irish.

Apart from that consideration, this insistence on a pass in Irish does not help the language. It is not generally realised that Irish as a subject is much easier and the standard required is much easier, than most other subjects. As a teacher, I would be prepared to prove this. Because of the anxiety which exists about it, the student may be affected in the examination. While I suggest that the award of the certificate should not depend on success in Irish, I consider that the study of the Irish language should be compulsory for the entire school period. I would hope that if a pass in Irish were no longer compulsory, there would be no reduction in the time allocated to Irish in the school, which is now two and a half hours or three hours a week. In fact, I would hope that that allocation would be increased.

I spoke earlier about the tragedy of education as I saw it for what could be described as the disadvantaged underprivileged pupil coming from the culture or sub-culture of his home into this new culture ordained for him at school. I have spoken sufficiently about that to indicate my concern.

MainHeading.P: I would venture to say a word now on the question of teachers. I should express renewed congratulations to the Minister for the manner in which he has satisfied to a worthwhile degree the many and wide complaints which we get from our three teacher organisations. Here I must return, I am afraid, to an old endemic problem. I was hoping that, in so far as he has recognised teachers of manual subjects in the matter of the allocation up to a certain point, he might in the years ahead have a second look at that and agree to give to any teacher in any school the same recognition.

If we are to suggest that technical education is comparable with or as desirable as academic education I do not think we will convince even the students that that is so when they realise that somebody is treated differently because he has a BA degree than somebody who might be a far better teacher and who teaches subjects which did not require his graduating at one of the universities but who must accept less money. That is not a situation that can be sustained.

On the question of teachers generally, the Department must now have a look at what I call recruitment for the teaching profession. For far too long it has been accepted that the higher the educational and academic qualifications the better the teacher. Those of us who have had any association with teaching will appreciate that does not hold, having regard to the important work the teacher is obliged to carry out. It is unlike any other profession. In medicine, if a person goes to a bad doctor he has a second chance——

Speaker.P: Not always.

Invariably, we will say. If he is alive he will have another opportunity. The same applies to an engineer or an architect: if you meet a bad one you can discard him and move to another. As far as teaching is concerned, the student, the client, has not that second opportunity. A student may find himself in the class of a teacher possibly with excellent degrees but a person who found himself teaching because he thought it would be a worthwhile occupation but who, having arrived, discovered he had not got the patience, the personality, the characteristics which would make him a suitable person to carry out the duties required of him. Unfortunately, however, the pupil has to spend possibly two years in the charge of that teacher.
Unless he gets elected to the Dáil.
Is the vote being given at 18?

The damage would have been done to those students who are so unfortunate and it can never be remedied. Therefore, I would hope that in the recruitment of teachers in the future regard will be had for the character, the personality, of the teacher as well as for his academic qualifications.

My final point in regard to primary schools will refer to my constituency. I will first of all have regard to what I think a school should be. I am disappointed particularly that since the advent of bad weather I have heard of so many schools where children having reported for classes were told there was no heating. Apart from anything else, if we are to try to educate children for life, for management and organisation, this is a poor example.

My most serious objection however is that when children are sent to school their mothers possibly go to a shop or to church or to work. The children in the circumstances which I have mentioned, are kept in the school for a half or three quarters of an hour. They are released at 10 o'clock and arrive at a home which is locked with the mammy missing. That situation should not be tolerated. Unfortunately, it has occurred in a few schools in my constituency. I would allow for a genuine emergency but where it occurs with such frequency as to suggest lack of interest or concern on the part of the school manager, I suggest the Department should take serious not of it.

MainHeading.P: From an economic point of view alone, I do not see why the Department do not insist on permanent caretakers being employed in all national schools. The school in which I operated was blessed with an exemplary caretaker and I would be prepared to show that on economic grounds alone that gentleman, who possibly received £19 or £20 a week, was worth at least three times that amount. It pains me when I go into relatively new schools, built two or three years, in which we try to impress on children the importance of colour, neatness and tidyness, and do not see reflected in those establishments the ideas we try to inculcate in the students.

On the question of school structures, it is not always wise to generalise from one's experience in one's own district, but I am concerned about Old Cabra. The school was built there when the area was first populated and when there was a large number of young children. They are not there in the same numbers now and the school is only half or three-quarters occupied. Perhaps in such cases the Department would consider the building not a continuation or development of the prefabricated emergency buildings but something less expensive than the brick building. I understand that there are on the market other buildings with a guaranteed life of 20 to 25 years. From what I have seen happening in areas like Old Cabra and West Cabra, where the original structures are there and only half occupied, it might be wise to think in terms of a structure which would last 20 to 25 years and which could be transported from one area to another.

I think I have expressed most of the thoughts I had when rising. As always happens when I resume my seat I shall discover that I have given too much time to detail and too little time to more important points. Knowing that already my reputation in the matter of my lack of regard for my fellowgraduates has gone ahead of me I shall add further to that which I have already said. We talk about educating for society and the people for whom we are making the policy but the people on whom we are imposing the policy have very little voice in it.

I shall venture to comment too on the situation that has arisen in the matter of one or two professions, most noticeably the legal profession. Some time ago I tabled a question to the Minister in which I sought information as to the number of BLs who had graduated during the last five years and I asked the Minister to indicate if possible the number who (1) were nonnationals and the number who (2) came from what would be described as the working-class people of Ireland. If our professions are to reflect society and what society wants, that society must have representation in these professions. The Minister unfortunately was unable to give me the information I asked for but I think I can make a fair attempt at answering the question myself. I think the number of students who have been called to the Bar in the last five, ten, 15 or 20 years and who have come from the lower income groups is very small. Moneys which are paid out of the public purse towards educating people for the legal profession, a very important profession, come in the main, from our taxpayers who are mostly what are described as working-class people. I hope the representatives of those people will find their place in that profession.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins
Speaker.P: I hope the House will bear with me. I had intended to do some homework on this Estimate during the weekend but because of the situation of the schools in my constituency it proved impossible. I find myself at a disadvantage speaking on this Estimate because all the speakers who have gone before me are or have been members of the teaching profession and, more noticably still, all are from the eastern seaboard. I have noticed in the Department of Education over the last few years a tendency to generalise, to apply standards which obtain in Dublin to rural Ireland. You cannot do this.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Thornley criticised those of us who thought small schools were a good thing. To me, coming from rural Ireland, there is nothing better than the small school. Children get individual attention, they know their teachers and, in many schools in my constituency anyway, they get a very high standard of education in primary schools. Primary schools are the most important of all schools. They are the basis of all our education. What is education? Our aim when we educate is surely to draw out the possibilities and potentials of each child and to make the best of them. Primary schools heretofore did this. I understand the economics of this and obviously where schools were very small it became necessary to close them. I am glad to note that the Department have slowed down the rate of closures of small schools. I do not know why this is.

Speaker.P: Transport has become too expensive.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Whatever it is it is a good thing. I have become increasingly aware of a slight deteriora-tion in the standard of pupils applying to become teachers in primary schools. I think this is because of the grants system. If a boy or girl gets four honours he or she qualifies for a grant. If a boy just gets one honour in Irish and one other he might chance St. Patrick's, or in the case of a girl she might chance the equivalent. I think this is a bad thing. The very best brains must be attracted into the teaching profession. I am appalled at the salaries paid to national teachers. I was speaking at the weekend to a teacher in my own parish who is on an extension. He has given service second to none. He spent much of his free time and his energy before what we call free education coaching children for scholarships. This teacher, and as far as I know he is a graduate, told me that on reaching the age of 67 he will not be earning £2,500 a year. I just sat there with my mouth open because £2,500 a year is considered “peanuts” in many professions. Young solicitors start with that. Young doctors, registrars in hospitals, start with that. Surely men and women who have given a lifetime of service should have better remuneration.

MainHeading.P: I represent a very large constituency. It takes in a slice of Roscommon, half of Galway and a great portion of Clare. In all the years I have been in this House representing this constituency I have never heard education discussed in terms of class. In this House tonight both Deputy Thornley and Deputy Tunney seemed to be obsessed with class distinction. I cannot understand this. Perhaps it is due to the fact that in rural Ireland the Christian Brothers, the De la Salle Brothers, the Mercy Nuns or the Presentation Nuns, educated all of our children before the free system came in, for a minimum fee. Therefore, children from all start attended secondary schools if they had the academic ability and were not so conscious of class distinction. This to me is quite a phenomenon and it is terribly apparent in the House tonight. The Deputies appear to consider that children who go to secondary schools in Dublin come from a different class from the ones who do not go on to secondary schools. This is crazy.

Speaker.P: It is a fact.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins
Speaker.P: I have a sort of muddled thinking on this and I suppose as a woman I will be forgiven this because we are not supposed to be logical. Children leaving primary schools should be screened in some way to see if they are fit for what we now term secondary education and whether they will eventually be fit for academic education. The ambition of most parents in rural Ireland is to have their children go to the secondary school and get the leaving certificate. This is a mistake because most children are not material for leaving certificates. I see this in my own children. I am quite convinced that my eldest daughter is academically inclined but I do not believe that the next girl will even pass her intermediate certificate and for that reason I do not intend to push her. I am sure we shall find a niche for her somewhere and we shall train her for that end.

MainHeading.P: In rural Ireland—it has happened in my constituency at least—technical schools have become more or less secondary schools. I do not wish to be misunderstood. It is a good thing that children in technical schools should get their leaving certificates, et cetera, but there should be more emphasis on technical education. In Dublin and the larger centres there are superb technical schools the like of which do not exist in rural Ireland. Our technical schools have now become extensions of secondary schools or are run on parallel lines which is a mistake. Heretofore, vocational schools gave, particularly to girls who were not academically minded, very good basic domestic training. This seems to have gone. I have always thought it a great mistake that boys did not get some domestic training. As a nation we leave the wives to do all domestic chores and all the rearing of families and the husbands opt out. This is largely because of the way the boys were brought up; they were never shown or trained in or taught anything with even a slightly domestic flavour to it.

It is important that children should be told at a fairly early age, about 14 or 15, that they obviously will not be material for university but could do very well in technology and industry. A child should be told this and should be proud of it. Deputy Tunney seemed to think that children trained as technicians are second-class citizens. Surely this is the age of technology, computers and so on, and as time goes on it would seem that technicians and people with specialised skills will be the people who will get the jobs. A great many graduates with excellent degrees and qualifications have to emigrate to earn a living but I think we have plently of scope for technicians at home.

My constituency has a number of small secondary schools for girls, excellent in themselves and run mostly by the Mercy Order. Early this year three of them, Eyrecourt, Woodford and Kinvara, were notified by the Department that as from this year they would cease to be senior cycle schools, in other words they could not present candidates for the leaving certificate. The manner in which this announcement was conveyed showed gross bad manners. We live in an age in which manners do not seem to count but surely nuns and teachers who have given a generation of service are entitled to at least a visit from an official of the Department to discuss the ending of senior cycle education instead of what I would describe as a rude letter dismissing them.

I attended a protest meeting at Kinvara last night—that is why I did not do my homework. That school was opened as a secondary school in 1924, residential and non-residential. Since then it has produced superb results. It is an excellent school and the Department must be aware that it never sought too much by way of grants and that the nuns ploughed back a great deal of their money into keeping the school going. The parents and the nuns are very disturbed. Woodford is in a slightly different position in that it is a more modern school, is co-educational and has larger numbers, about 170, but it is in the same category. On the day the Mother Superior received a letter from the Department telling her she would no longer have a senior cycle she also had a visit from an official of the Department to tell her she could go ahead and build two extra class rooms. She showed him the letter and he muttered that somebody did not tell him something. It appears there is need for more liaison in the Minister's Department. Woodford is in south Galway, up in the mountains, and parents tell me that if their children are transported to Portumna they will be travelling, some of them, 22 miles each morning and 22 miles each evening. They are very alarmed about this.

We in rural Ireland are aware that the form of education the parents bargain for when sending their children to school by bus is not the form they are getting. This has to be seen to be believed in some cases. Parents have told me of their concern about those long bus journeys and the inevitable waiting at one end or the other on occasions. In some cases parents have taken the children off the buses and got them to cycle to school. In other cases, at great expense to themselves, they have sent the children to boarding school because of those long bus journeys.

Eyrecourt, the third school in my constituency, is a small new school, about nine or ten years old which has only about 100 students but it is an excellent school and gave great service to the community. We, in rural Ireland realise, whether the Minister does or not, that if you take a secondary school out of a small town you damage also the economic and social life of the town. The rural strata is based on schools. I feel very strongly about transporting children in buses over long distances. It must be done in some cases. In certain cases children leave for school at 7.30 or 8 a.m. and return about 7.30 or 8 p.m. These children are being educated away from their homes and, in the case of boys, away from the land.

I spoke to a parent last night, a quite substantial farmer whose greatest regret was that he had sent his son to a secondary school. I said: “We want farmers with a fairly good standard of education in the EEC.” His answer was that since they sent their son John to secondary school he never saw a cow or even the land and how could he be interested in something he never saw and to which he was not geared? I think this is a dire situation. I do not know if the Minister is familiar with the area west of the Shannon but the population there is declining every year. If we educate our children away from their homes, then they will never go back to stay in their homes. If the boys do not go back the girls will not stay because there will be no one for them to marry.

We are missing out on one facet of education, farming education. I know there are schools and facilities in the universities but something will have to be done at grassroots level for the benefit of the boys and girls who intend to stay on the land. They will have to be given a better technical training in farming. In the light of the EEC it is most important that they should get the very best training they can. For too long our farmers mooched along doing things any-old-how. Now they are adapting to modern methods and modern conditions. Even in primary school the children should have visits from the local agricultural instructor who would give them talks on agriculture. The vocational schools should have a close liaison with the agricultural section of the county council. The children should be kept up-to-date on modern farming methods.

My constituency has unfortunately a high incidence of mental handicap. I do not know why this should be. There are all sorts of theories. Every weekend unfortunate mothers come to me and tell me that a child is mildly mentally handicapped and therefore not eligible for St. Raphael's; the nearest school then is in Athlone and it is mainly for mongoloid children. These mothers tell me they are nearly demented because they do not know what to do and their husbands do not understand the problem. A great deal more will have to be done by way of making schools available for mentally handicapped children. Were it not for the invaluable work done by the religious orders we would be very lacking in facilities for these children. The Minister should try to get more money for these schools. These children belong to the weakest section of the community and they will always be a problem for both the parents and the community.

I would ask the Minister to look again at the small schools. West of the Shannon we could not possibly get 400 in a school. There are not 400 adults in most areas, not to mention 400 children. It might be a good idea to make these schools co-educational. If that were done one might get 150 or 200 pupils, but one will never get 400. I think co-education is excellent. We have had one experience in Woodford in which the results have been extraordinarily good. The teachers tell me that the girls cannot bear to see the boys beat them and the boys cannot bear the idea of the girls being better and so they are all breaking their necks to secure higher marks. The experiment there has been a very happy one. The male teachers find the girls easy to handle and the nuns are well able to handle the boys. There cannot be a hard and fast rule for this area. There must be no regulation saying you must have 400 students before you can have a senior cycle school. In fairness to the Minister, I should tell the House that these schools have been given a reprieve of four years. I imagine that is for the purpose of enabling the present students to complete their courses. But this is a slow, lingering death. I appeal to the Minister to reverse his decision and to allow the schools to continue for the next ten or 12 years until we see what the population trend is.

Speaker.P: I am not by any stretch of the imagination an authority on education but I am very concerned about education. I happen to be the father of a large family of school-going children. I am also chairman of the Vocational Education Committee in County Dublin, one of the busiest committees in the whole country and with more responsibility than any other committee in the country because of the rapid rate of expansion in County Dublin.

We have all sorts of problems. One thing that almost frightens me is the fact that we have practically no framework of legislation for education. It frightens me to think of what the Minister can do by simple decree or order. Will we ever have an Education Act under which those providing the education will know what they can do and what the Minister can impose on them? By an over-night announcement, outside of this House altogether, the Minister can tell those people what they have to do and almost what they must think. This is a shocking situation. By decree or order the Minister can ordain fantastic changes in educational policy without any discussion here in this House. The greatest example of this in recent times was the way in which the matter of the community schools was handled.

I am one of those who is wholly in favour of the whole concept of community schools. It is an excellent idea and I believe it would have been accepted wholeheartedly in the area I represent if it had been properly put before the people and the people given the opportunity of considering all the implications in the knowledge that their views would get sincere consideration in the Department. Very early on I made an effort to get the Minister back on the rails, so to speak, before he went too far, but I failed to do so. The people are putting him back on the rails nows. He sent his inspectors, excellent people, down the country to make the various announcements and they were lucky to get back with their lives, almost. They were thrown out of the various areas; here was someone coming down from Dublin to tell the people what was good for them and, whether they liked it or not, they were going to get it.

MainHeading.P: This is all wrong. Many of the wrongs that were obvious earlier in regard to the community school proposals have been rectified since but it would have been much better if there had been a certain amount of discussion of people's view on this whole matter before they were told that this was the type of school they were to have. Last July the Minister made an announcement to the effect that after full consultation with the parties concerned he had made certain decisions in respect of community schools for Tallaght and Blanchardstown. In these two areas the County Dublin Vocational Education Committee were providing the only post-primary education that was available. There was no consultation with them. The only attempt at consultation took place at 4 o'clock on a Friday afternoon when there was a telephone call for me asking me to go to the Department where I would be told of the announcement that was to appear in the newspapers on the following morning.

Speaker.P: Fianna Fáil consultation.
Fine Gael consternation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Rightly so.

When the 'phone call came through I was in Cork and the CEO went to the Department where he was shown the text of what was to be circulated to the papers that evening. That was regarded as consultation.
Full consultation.

When I confronted the Minister with this instance at Question Time his answer was that he had consulted with the vocational education organisation for the country as a whole. Had he been talking to the organisation representing the country in regard to two schools the type of which was to be peculiar and particular to Tallaght and Blanchardstown only? That is not playing the game. It was not giving sufficient recognition to what I consider to be the busiest committee at present in the country and the committee which probably have the greatest responsibility.

MainHeading.P: We know from the draft census that out of a population increase in the last six years of 80,000, approximately 55,000 are in County Dublin. We know what that means in terms of problems for everybody charged with responsibility for providing educational facilities. The problems are enormous and I know that the Minister has a difficult job in trying to provide facilities in an area growing as rapidly as the one with which I am concerned. I know the problems that this involves for the officials of his Department but many of the problems could be eased if the job was tackled in the way that it should be tackled.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Offaly School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the title difficulties relating to the levels on which his Department proposes to build a new national school at Shinrone, County Offaly have now been resolved; if so, when building is likely to commence; and if he will make a full statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Faulkner) Padraig Faulkner
Speaker.P: Satisfactory evidence of title to the main portion of the site for the new school has been furnished. Title to the remaining plot has not yet been fully cleared but it is expected that good title to this portion will be forthcoming shortly.

My Department are now in a position to sanction forthwith a grant for the erection of the new school. When the grant has been sanctioned it will be a matter for the Commissioners of Public Works to make the arrangements for the erection of the school.
It is not possible to say at this stage when building work will commence.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. J. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Persons who complain that dental services are not available are advised that treatment under the dental benefit scheme is still available from a substantial number of dentists who have remained on the dental panel.
